story.kicker_image_caption: India 70th in the Good Country Index
story.storykicker: The list has been prepared on the basis of each country's contribution to the planet through their policy and behaviour.
story.storybody:
In a recently released report of Good Country Index (GCI) 2015, India has been placed at the 70th position. The list has ranked a total of 163 countries and Sweden has been ranked at the number one position. The list has been prepared on the basis of each country's contribution to the planet through their behaviour and policy.

Here is all you should know:

  • Sweden has topped the list of good countries
  • Sweden is followed by Denmark, Netherlands, United Kingdom, Germany, Finland, Canada, France, Austria, and New Zealand
  • According to the Good Country Index, the least good country is Libya
  • The Index is prepared after collecting statistics of 35 categories and indicators which are mostly generated by the United Nations

The categories and indicators are:

Science, Technology & Knowledge

Culture

International Peace and Security

World Order

Planet and Climate

Prosperity and Equality

Health and Wellbeing

{mosimage}

 

  • India's best ranking (27th) was in 'International Peace and Security', while the worst (124th) was in 'Prosperity and Equality'
  • India stands at 37th position in 'Health and Wellbeing', 62nd in 'Science and Technology', 119th in 'Culture', 106th in 'Planet and Climate' and 100th in 'World Order'
  • Sweden has ranked highest for prosperity, equality, health and well-being
  • In the Science and Technology sector, the United Kingdom's growth has placed the country at the 4th position
  • Iceland tops the list for overall contribution to 'The Planet and Climate Protection'
  • In 2014, the top countries in the list were Ireland, Finland and Switzerland. The last three countries on the list were Iraq, Libya and Vietnam.

 Interested in General Knowledge and Current Affairs? Click here to stay informed and know what is happening around the world with our G.K. and Current Affairs section.
